title: Normal Distribution Percentiles
description: For X ~ N(50, 100), find the value x such that P(X < x) = 0.95.
hints: Find z such that P(Z < z) = 0.95 (z ≈ 1.645)
solution:
From standard normal table: P(Z < 1.645) ≈ 0.95

Convert to X scale:
x = μ + zσ = 50 + 1.645(10)
= 50 + 16.45 = 66.45

title: Empirical Rule
description: For a normal distribution with mean 80 and standard deviation 5, approximately what percentage of values fall between 70 and 90?
hints: Empirical rule: about 95% within 2 standard deviations
solution:
The interval [70, 90] is [μ - 2σ, μ + 2σ]

By the empirical rule, approximately 95% of values fall within 2 standard deviations of the mean.

Answer: About 95%

title: Uniform Distribution

title: Chi-Square Distribution
description: If Z₁, Z₂, Z₃ are independent standard normal random variables, what is the distribution of Y = Z₁² + Z₂² + Z₃²? What are E[Y] and Var(Y)?
hints: Sum of k squared independent standard normals has chi-square distribution with k degrees of freedom
solution:
Y = Z₁² + Z₂² + Z₃² follows a chi-square distribution with 3 degrees of freedom: Y ~ χ²(3)

E[Y] = 3
Var(Y) = 2(3) = 6

title: Normal Approximation to Binomial
description: A coin is flipped 100 times. Use the normal approximation to estimate P(X ≥ 55) where X is the number of heads.
hints: Approximate with Normal: μ = np = 50, σ² = np(1-p) = 25
Use continuity correction: P(X ≥ 55) ≈ P(Y > 54.5) where Y ~ N(50, 25)

title: t-Distribution
description: Explain when to use the t-distribution instead of the normal distribution. What happens to the t-distribution as degrees of freedom increase?
hints: Consider sample size and whether population variance is known
Think about the shape of t vs normal
solution:
Use the t-distribution when:
1. Sample size is small (typically n < 30)
2. Population standard deviation σ is unknown
3. Population is approximately normal

As degrees of freedom (df) increase, the t-distribution approaches the standard normal distribution N(0,1). With df ≥ 30, they are nearly identical.

The t-distribution has heavier tails than normal, accounting for additional uncertainty from estimating σ.

title: Poisson as Limit of Binomial
description: Show that when n is large and p is small such that np = λ remains constant, the Binomial(n,p) approaches Poisson(λ). Use n=100, p=0.02, λ=2.
solution:
For Binomial(100, 0.02):
P(X=3) = C(100,3)(0.02)³(0.98)⁹⁷
≈ 161,700 × 8×10⁻⁶ × 0.133 ≈ 0.182

For Poisson(2):
P(X=3) = (2³ e⁻²)/3! = 8(0.1353)/6 ≈ 0.180

The values are very close, demonstrating the Poisson approximation to Binomial.

title: Distribution Comparison
description: Compare and contrast the Binomial and Poisson distributions. When would you use each?
hints: Consider the type of data each models
Think about parameters and typical applications
solution:
Binomial Distribution:
- Fixed number of trials n
- Each trial has probability p of success
- Counts successes in n trials
- Two parameters: n and p
- Use for: coin flips, quality control with fixed sample size

Poisson Distribution:
- Models rare events
- Events occur at constant average rate λ
- Counts events in fixed interval
- One parameter: λ
- Use for: arrivals per hour, defects per unit, calls per day

Poisson approximates Binomial when n is large, p is small, and np = λ is moderate.
